awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A STEM curriculum platform using augmented reality for real-time collaboration and problem solving
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to use augmented reality (AR) to activate rich and measurable STEM experiences such as engineering design projects for any child anywhere in the world. The market for AR globally and specifically in education is projected to reach over $200 B and $60 B respectively by 2025 by growing at 40% annually.Next Generation Science Standards support the premise that students should be learning the skills of science and engineering by engaging in work like that of scientists and engineers. According to the US STEM 2026 report, core competencies from effective STEM education will be demanded in nearly all job sectors and positions. The proposed technology integrates augmented reality and embedded data collection and analysis for real-time assessment for STEM projects in a classroom environment. By measuring both processes and outcomes, this project can better nurture growth mindsets. The proposed features will reinforce these key pedagogical approaches to promote STEM learning and prepare students with essential STEM career readiness skills. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project proposes to integrate augmented reality into the engineering design process while nurturing higher-level skills essential for workforce success and measuring key learning processes and skills. The data collection, storage, reproduction, analyses and algorithm development, while founded in research, remain sources of technical risk in the field of educational augmented reality. The proposed system encourages students to acknowledge and reflect on their emotions and takes an integrated approach to measuring students social and emotional learning (SEL) during collaborative activities. The research will determine how and to what extent do these activities support elementary students to: 1) develop design thinking and collaborative practices; 2) improve social and emotional skills in collaborative settings; and 3) impact students’ content knowledge, interest and self-efficacy in science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This report will detail how our team at Explore Interactive, Inc. (EI) met each of the technical objectives for the grant #2134765, the NSF SBIR Phase II: A STEM curriculum platform using augmented reality (AR) for real-time collaboration and problem solving.  In the Phase I SBIR grant, EI completed three key technical objectives to build a collaborative AR learning environment.  This included the capability for students to work together to build circuits and activities to practice fixing circuits within the platform. The team’s work was motivated by the gap elementary educators described in their knowledge and tools for the teaching and implementation of Next Generation Science Standards in the area of engineering design practices. Thus in terms of broader impact, the project develops educators in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and contributes to developing a more competitive STEM workforce.  For the Phase II work, the flagship feature developed was an integrated engineering design notebook and other data rich interactions to measure collaborative and interpersonal skills.  This notebook is now available to students throughout their STEM activities. To provide this student work to educators, we implemented a new web based platform. This platform allows educators to manage basic tasks like classroom rosters and grouping students to work together. It also features a newsfeed where students' work in the AR environment and notebook are easily viewed to facilitate class discussion or provide instant awareness of issues with collaboration conflicts.  Student work is viewable by both students and educators and feedback is enabled through comment and like features.  We also designed and developed the technology necessary for proprietary data collection and preliminary processing of the data for analysis towards measuring STEM practices.  One example of these is a replay feature that allows students and educators to view an animation that demonstrates the exact order of steps students took to create their designs. A second example is prototypes of data tables to combine individual actions of students so educators can identify trends. One type of data for this type of trend identification is the frequency in which students give a thumbs up vs. a thumbs down to a teammate for their effort. This is novel as collaboration and process metrics are not available in any other known platform, thus generating the ability for the first time for educators to gain key insights into the progression of students through engineering design projects. The development of the notebook and data collection features was the result of a successful collaboration between Filament Games (FG)  and EI engineers on key technical objectives of the grant. A second project outcome was a new content unit in AR to give more incentive to educators to adopt the new technology approach, as district purchasers seek more comprehensive classroom materials. The unit features simple machines like a screw, lever, inclined plane, pulley, and wheel in combination with a pendulum and spring.  These pieces may be combined in infinite combinations as students complete design challenges to construct a course (like a Rube Goldberg machine) to score a goal.  This required the development of new curricular materials and training, which focused on Forces and Motion through simple machines and elements of the design process such as seeking feedback from stakeholders to determine criteria for success and constraints such as budget. These tasks were assisted by the teachers funded by Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) supplement. The teachers also provided feedback on each new feature in the design phase. Preliminary and final classroom testing of the tool with subcontractor State University of New York at Buffalo was conducted to achieve our usability, feasibility and effectiveness studies. In 2024, we received and completed the objectives of the Technology Enhancement for Commercial Partnerships (TECP) supplement with the Boston Museum of Science.  This work enabled the notebook to be customized for different customers or applications, and critically expanded the reach of the notebook capabilities to other languages as well as physical projects.  These improvements were also separately classroom tested.  Throughout the process teachers and students provided feedback to the development of the final product, an app called MindLabs STEM, which is now available for download in the Apple App store and the Google Play Store on tablet devices and is accompanied by the web platform hosted at www.learnwithexplore.com. The product is also launched at two distributors - STEMfinity and STEM Education Works and is also available for direct purchase at the MindLabs website.  The project work was featured twice in the Chicago Tribune, a collaborative blog post was written by the Boston Museum of Science and a paper is under review at the Journal of Pre-College Engineering Education Research.  We showcased the work in the Department of Education ED Games Expo in 2023 and were the winner of the PitchFest at FETC in the Immersive Technology category.
